description: From Middle English plomme, ploume, from Old English pl큰me, from Proto-West Germanic *pl큰m훮, borrowed from Latin pr큰num. Doublet of prune.

adjectives.description: plum (comparative more plum, superlative most plum)

entries.meaning: (comparable) Of a dark bluish-red colour.
(not comparable) Choice; especially lavish or preferred.
examples: She landed a plum position as an executive for the firm.

entries.meaning: An edible, fleshy stone fruit of Prunus domestica (European plum), often of a dark red or purple colour. [from 8th c.]
A stone-fruit tree which bears this fruit, Prunus domestica. [from 8th c.]
The edible, fleshy stone fruit of several species resembling the plum, or the tree from which they grow. [from 16th c.]
Prunus sect. Prunus
Prunus cerasifera (cherry plum or myrobalan)
Prunus salicina (Chinese plum or Japanese plum)
Prunus spinosa (sloe)
Prunus ursina (bear's plum)
Prunus sect. Prunocerasus North American plums
Prunus americana (American plum)
Prunus angustifolia (Chickasaw plum or sand plum)
Prunus hortulana (hortulan plum)
Prunus nigra (Canadian plum or black plum)
Prunus rivularis (creek plum or hog plum)
Prunus subcordata (Klamath plum or Oregon plum)
Prunus sect. Armeniaca (better known as apricots)
Prunus mume, an Asian fruit more closely related to the apricot than the plum, usually consumed pickled, dried, or as a juice or wine; ume.
(now rare) A dried grape or raisin, as used in a pudding or cake. [from 17th c.]
(now rare, archaic) One hundred thousand pounds; (generally) a fortune. [from 18th c.]
A desirable or choice thing of its kind; a prize selection; a choice appointment, assignment etc. [from 19th c.]
examples: The mayor rewarded his cronies with cushy plums, requiring little work for handsome pay.

entries.meaning: A dark bluish-red color/colour, the colour of some plums. [from 19th c.]
(slang, usually in the plural) A testicle. [from 20th c.]
(derogatory, chiefly UK) A fool, an idiot.

adjectives.description: plum (comparative more plum, superlative most plum)

entries.meaning: Plumb
Completely; utterly.
examples: You're going to think I'm plum crazy for this, but I want to adopt all seven kittens.

verbs.description: plum (third-person singular simple present plums, present participle plumming, simple past and past participle plummed)

entries.meaning: (mining) To plumb.
